message.content:
The Golden Gate Bridge is a suspension bridge spanning the Golden Gate Strait, the entrance to the San Francisco Bay from the Pacific Ocean. It connects San Francisco on California's northern tip with Marin County to its north.

Construction of this iconic American landmark began on January 5, 1933 and ended with completion on April 19, 1937. The bridge opened to pedestrians for the first time on May 27th, 1937 and then to vehicles on May 28th, both in celebration of its completion.

Famed for its distinctive orange color (International Orange), it was chosen over navy blue and gray because it provided better visibility for passing ships during foggy conditions that are common in San Francisco Bay area. At a cost of approximately $35 million at that time (equivalent to about $1.2 billion today adjusted for inflation) it was an astounding architectural feat considering there were no federal or state funds used; financing came primarily from bonds issued by The Golden Gate Bridge Authority.
